{{Expand Russian|Люблинская, Александра Дмитриевна|topic=bio|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Alexandra D. Lublinskaya | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1902 | birth_place = | death_date = January 22, 1980 | death_place = | nationality = Russian | other_names = Historian | occupation = | known_for = }} '''Alexandra Dmitrievna Lublinskaya''' (May 27, 1902 – January 22, 1980)<ref name=lossky>Andrew Lossky, [http://www.ranumspanat.com/lublinskaya_obit.htm Alexandra Lublinskaya: A "valedictory salute"]{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''Nouvelles de la République des Lettres'', 2 (1981), pp. 204-08</ref> was a Russian scholar specialising in the history of seventeenth-century France, among other things.<ref>Beik, William (1985) [https://books.google.com/books?id=C-gtvGjSPTMC&pg=PR16&dq=A.+D.+Lublinskaya&hl=en&sa=X&ei=rCgeUojhHIup7Qa94IGYBg&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=Lublinskaya&f=false ''Absolutism and Society in Seventeenth-Century France: State Power and Provincial Aristocracy in Languedoc'', p. 26. Cambridge University Press] At Google Books. Retrieved 28 August 2013.</ref>
Her ''French Absolutism'', originally published in Russian in 1965, and translated into English by [[Brian Pearce]], with a foreword by [[J. H. Elliott]],<ref>[[Elliott, J. H.]] (2005) [https://books.google.com/books?id=C6gRm3Ie7DQC&pg=PA120&dq=The+Struggle+for+Stability+in+Early+Modern+Europe&hl=en&sa=X&ei=BwIeUrv5PKGM7AasnIH4DA&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=Lublinskaya&f=false "Debate without End" in Benedict, Philip & Myron P. Gutmann, eds. ''Early Modern Europe: From Crisis to Stability'', p. 39. University of Delaware Press.] At Google Books. Retrieved 28 August 2013.</ref> was published by [[Cambridge University Press]] in 1968.<ref>[https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/563060?uid=2129&uid=2&uid=70&uid=4&sid=21102643981147 French Absolutism: The Crucial Phase, 1620-1629 (review)], ''[[The English Historical Review]]'', Vol. 85, No. 334, Jan., 1970</ref><ref>C.B.A. Behrens, [http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/1970/jan/01/looking-for-the-ancien-regime/?pagination=false "Looking for the Ancien Régime"], ''[[New York Review of Books]]'', January 1, 1970</ref><ref>[http://fs.oxfordjournals.org/content/XXIV/2/174.extract French Absolutism: review], ''[[French Studies]]'', Volume XXIV, Issue 2, Pp. 174-175</ref><ref>[http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1468-0289.1969.tb00179.x/abstract Reviews], ''[[The Economic History Review]]'', Volume 22, Issue 2, pages 342–391, August 1969</ref> It is a criticism of the [[The General Crisis|general crisis of the 17th century]] thesis proposed by [[Hugh Trevor-Roper]]. The "general crisis" thesis generated controversy between supporters of this theory and those, such as the Marxist historian [[Eric Hobsbawm]], who believed in the "general crisis," but saw the problems of 17th-century Europe as more social and economic in origin than Trevor-Roper would allow. A third faction comprised those who simply denied there was any "general crisis," including Lublinskaya, Dutch historian Ivo Schöffer and the Danish historian Niels Steengsgaard.<ref>Rabb, Theodore K.''The Struggle for Stability in Early Modern Europe'', New York: Oxford University Press, 1975 pages 20–21 & 25–26.</ref>
Her professional publications number over 200, on a great variety of topics, but can be broken into three categories: works on [[paleography]], critical publication of historical documents, and monographs and articles on the social and political history of medieval and early modern France ("[[middle ages]]" in Soviet chronology extended to about 1650).<ref name=lossky/>
Her ''[[Masterpiece|magnum opus]]'' was a series of books on the history of the administration of [[Cardinal Richelieu|Richelieu]].<ref name=lossky/> The first book was ''Frantsiia v nachale XVII veka'' (1610-1622 gg.) "France at the beginning of the 17th century, 1610-1620" published in 1959. This was followed by ''French Absolutism: the Crucial Phase, 1620-1629'' in 1965. A third book was published just before her death covering the years 1630-42.<ref name=lossky/> Another major work was ''Frantsuzskie krest'iane v XVI-XVIII vv.'' ("French peasants in the 16th-18th centuries"), published in 1978.
==English editions== *''French Absolutism: The Crucial Phase, 1620-1629''. Cambridge University Press (2008)

'''Akakor''' is the name of a mythological ancient underground city, located somewhere between [[Brazil]], [[Bolivia]] and [[Peru]].
It was described by German journalist [[Karl Brugger]], based on interviews with a self-proclaimed Brazilian Indian chieftain [[Tatunca Nara]] in his book ''The Chronicle of Akakor'' (1976). Although Brugger was apparently convinced, the information in it has only one source (Tatunca Nara), who was later exposed by activist and adventurer [[Rüdiger Nehberg]] as being Günther Hauck, a German.
Elements of the story from ''The Chronicle of Akakor'' were used in the film ''[[Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull]]'', where they were conflated with [[El Dorado]], although references are to "Akator".<ref>[http://cinefantastiqueonline.com/2008/05/10/film-preview-part-one-indiana-jones-kingdom-of-the-crystal-skull/ Film Preview (Pt. I): Indiana Jones & the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull]</ref>

{{Other uses}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2017}} {| width="auto" style="toc: 25em; font-size: 85%; lucida grande, sans-serif; text-align: left;" class="infobox" |- ! colspan="4" text-align="center" bgcolor="#CCCCFF"|'''United States of America''' |- | colspan="4" align="center"|[[File:Flag of the United States.svg|center|border|180px]] |- | colspan="4" align="center"|[[File:United States (orthographic projection).svg|center|180px]] |} The '''American Century'''Lamb, Brian, and Harold Evans. The American Century. West Lafayette, IN: C-SPAN Archives, 1999.[http://www.randomhouse.com/features/americancentury/frame.html The American Century]. randomhouse.com. is a characterization of the period since the middle of the 20th century as being largely dominated by the United States in political, economic, and cultural terms. It is comparable to the description of the period 1815–1914 as [[Britain's Imperial Century]].{{Cite book|first=Ronald|last=Hyam|title=Britain's Imperial Century, 1815–1914: A Study of Empire and Expansion|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|year=2002|isbn=978-0-7134-3089-9|url=https://books.google.com/?id=2eMoHQAACAAJ|accessdate=December 15, 2013}} The United States' influence grew throughout the 20th century, but became especially dominant after the end of [[World War II]], when only two superpowers remained, the United States and the [[Soviet Union]]. After the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]] in 1991, the United States remained the world's only superpower,{{cite web|url=http://post.queensu.ca/~nossalk/papers/hyperpower.htm|title=Analyzing American Power in the Post-Cold War Era|accessdate=February 28, 2007| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070311021450/http://post.queensu.ca/~nossalk/papers/hyperpower.htm| archivedate= March 11, 2007 | deadurl= no}} and became the [[hegemon]], or what some have termed a [[hyperpower]].[http://www.wordspy.com/words/hyper-power.asp Definition and Use of the Word ''Hyperpower''] ==Origin of the phrase== The term was coined by ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' publisher [[Henry Luce]] to describe what he thought the role of the United States would be and should be during the 20th century.David Harvey, ''The New Imperialism'', (New York: Oxford University Press, 2003) Luce, the son of a missionary, in a February 17, 1941 ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' magazine editorial[[Henry Luce|Luce, Henry]] (February 17, 1941) [https://books.google.com/books?id=I0kEAAAAMBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=century&f=false The American Century], ''[[Life Magazine]]'' urged the United States to forsake [[isolationism]] for a missionary's role, acting as the world's [[Good Samaritan]] and spreading democracy. He called upon the US to enter [[World War II]] to defend democratic values:
Throughout the 17th century and the 18th century and the 19th century, this continent teemed with manifold projects and magnificent purposes. Above them all and weaving them all together into the most exciting flag of all the world and of all history was the triumphal purpose of freedom.
It is in this spirit that all of us are called, each to his own measure of capacity, and each in the widest horizon of his vision, to create the first great American Century.Luce, H. R: "The American Century" reprinted in ''The Ambiguous Legacy'', M. J. Hogan, ed. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1999.
Democracy and other American ideals would "do their mysterious work of lifting the life of mankind from the level of the beasts to what the Psalmist called a little lower than the angels". Only under the American Century can the world "come to life in any nobility of health and vigor".Henry Luce, "The American Century", ''Life'', (February 17, 1941): pp. 64–65, https://books.google.co.il/books?id=I0kEAAAAMBAJ&printsec=frontcover&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=century&f=false According to [[David Harvey (geographer)|David Harvey]], Luce believed "the power conferred was global and universal rather than territorially specific, so Luce preferred to talk of an American century rather than an empire".David Harvey, ''The New Imperialism'', (New York: Oxford University Press, 2003), 50. In the same article he called upon United States "to exert upon the world the full impact of our influence, for such purposes as we see fit and by such means as we see fit".Michael J. Hogan, ''The ambiguous legacy: U.S. foreign relations in the "American century"'', (Cambridge University Press, 1999), [https://books.google.com/books?id=T_QfEZw6hKkC&pg=PA20 p. 20]. ==Early characteristics== [[Image:GreaterAmericaMap.jpg|thumb|250px|Post-[[Spanish–American War]] map of "Greater America"]] Beginning at the end of the 19th century, with the [[Spanish–American War]] in 1898 and the [[Boxer Rebellion]], the United States began to play a more prominent role in the world beyond the North American continent. The government adopted [[protectionism]] after the Spanish–American War to develop its native industry and built up the navy, the "[[Great White Fleet]]". When [[Theodore Roosevelt]] became president in 1901, he accelerated a foreign policy shift away from [[isolationism]] and towards foreign involvement, a process which had begun under his predecessor [[William McKinley]]. For instance, the United States fought the [[Philippine–American War]] against the [[First Philippine Republic]] to solidify its control over the newly acquired Philippines.John M. Gates (August 1984) [http://www3.wooster.edu/History/jgates/book-ch3.html "War-Related Deaths in the Philippines"] ''Pacific Historical Review'' , v. 53, no. 3, 367–78. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140629045949/http://www3.wooster.edu/History/jgates/book-ch3.html |date=June 29, 2014 }} In 1904, Roosevelt committed the United States to building the [[Panama Canal]], creating the [[Panama Canal Zone]]. Interventionism found its formal articulation in the 1904 [[Roosevelt Corollary]] to the [[Monroe Doctrine]], proclaiming a right for the United States to intervene anywhere in the Americas, a moment that underlined the emergent US regional [[hegemony]]. After the outbreak of [[World War I]] in 1914, the United States pursued a policy of [[non-intervention]], avoiding conflict while trying to broker a peace. President [[Woodrow Wilson]] later argued that the war was so important that the US had to have a voice in the peace conference.{{harvnb|Karp|1979}} The United States was never formally a member of the [[Allies of World War I|Allies]] but entered the war in 1917 as a self-styled "Associated Power". Initially the United States had a small army, but, after the passage of the [[Selective Service Act of 1917|Selective Service Act]], it drafted 2.8 million men,{{cite web|url=http://www.sss.gov/induct.htm |title=Selective Service System: History and Records |publisher=Sss.gov |accessdate=July 27, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090507211238/http://www.sss.gov/induct.htm |archivedate=May 7, 2009 }} and, by summer 1918, was sending 10,000 fresh soldiers to France every day. The war ended in 1919 with the [[Treaty of Versailles]]. The United States then adopted a policy of [[isolationism]], having refused to endorse the 1919 [[Versailles Treaty]] or formally enter the [[League of Nations]].Kennedy, David M., ''Freedom From Fear: The American People in Depression and War, 1929–1945'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999) 386 During the interwar period, economic [[protectionism]] took hold in the United States, particularly as a result of the [[Smoot–Hawley Tariff Act]] which is credited by economists with the prolonging and worldwide propagation of the [[Great Depression]].{{cite book |title=International Financial Management, 6th Edition |author=Eun, Cheol S. |author2=Resnick, Bruce G. |year=2011 |publisher=McGraw-Hill/Irwin |location=New York |isbn=978-0-07-803465-7}}{{rp|33}} From 1934, [[trade liberalization]] began to take place through the [[Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act]]. With the onset of [[World War II]] in 1939, Congress loosened the [[Neutrality Acts of 1930s]] but remained opposed to entering the [[World War II in Europe|European war]].{{Harvnb|Schmitz|2000|p=124}}. In 1940, the United States ranked 18th in terms of military power.{{cite web|title=WWII Overview|url=http://www.nationalww2museum.org/learn/education/for-students/ww2-history/overview.html|publisher=The National WWII Museum|accessdate=February 28, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150305070506/http://www.nationalww2museum.org/learn/education/for-students/ww2-history/overview.html|archive-date=March 5, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}{{Cite web|url=http://ssi.armywarcollege.edu/pubs/summary.cfm?q=358|title=Excerpt – General George C. Marshall: Strategic Leadership and the Challenges of Reconstituting the Army, 1939–41|website=ssi.armywarcollege.edu|access-date=2018-01-23}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.politifact.com/texas/statements/2014/jun/13/ken-paxton/us-army-was-smaller-army-portugal-world-war-ii/|title=U.S. army was smaller than the army for Portugal before World War II|work=Politifact|access-date=2018-01-23}} The [[Neutrality Patrol]] had US destroyers fighting at sea, but no state of war had been declared by Congress. American public opinion remained isolationist. The 800,000-member [[America First Committee]] vehemently opposed any American intervention in the European conflict, even as the US sold military aid to the United Kingdom and the Soviet Union through the [[Lend-Lease]] program. In the 1941 State of the Union address, known as the [[Four Freedoms]] speech, President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] made a break with the tradition of [[non-interventionism]]. He outlined the US role in helping allies already engaged in warfare. By August, President Roosevelt and British Prime Minister [[Winston Churchill]] had drafted the [[Atlantic Charter]] to define goals for the post-war world.Langer and Gleason, chapter 21 In December 1941, Japan attacked American and British holdings with near-simultaneous [[Japanese expansion (1941–1942)|offensives against Southeast Asia and the Central Pacific]] including an [[attack on Pearl Harbor|attack on the US fleet at Pearl Harbor]].{{Harvnb|Wohlstetter|1962|pp=341–43}}. These attacks led the United States and United Kingdom to declare war on Japan. Three days later, Germany and Italy declared war on the United States, which the United States reciprocated.{{Harvnb|Dunn|1998|p=157}} In an effort to maintain peace after World War II,{{Harvnb|Yoder|1997|p=39}}. the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]] formed the [[United Nations]], which came into existence on October 24, 1945,{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/aboutun/history.htm|title=History of the UN|publisher=United Nations|accessdate=January 25, 2010}} and adopted the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] in 1948, as a common standard for all member states.{{Harvnb|Waltz|2002}} The U.S. worked closely with the United Kingdom to establish the [[IMF]], [[World Bank]] and [[NATO]].{{Cite news|url=http://rooseveltinstitute.org/special-relationship-between-great-britain-and-united-states-began-fdr/|title=The "Special Relationship" between Great Britain and the United States Began with FDR.|date=2010-07-22|work=Roosevelt Institute|access-date=2018-01-24|quote=and the joint efforts of both powers to create a new post-war strategic and economic order through the drafting of the Atlantic Charter; the establishment of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank; and the creation of the United Nations.}}{{Cite news|url=https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/the-press-office/2016/04/22/remarks-president-obama-and-prime-minister-cameron-joint-press|title=Remarks by the President Obama and Prime Minister Cameron in Joint Press Conference|date=2016-04-22|work=whitehouse.gov|access-date=2018-01-24|quote=That's what we built after World War II. The United States and the UK designed a set of institutions—whether it was the United Nations, or the Bretton Woods structure, IMF, World Bank, NATO, across the board.}} ==Pax Americana== {{Main|Pax Americana}} [[Pax Americana]] represents the relative [[peace]] in the Western world, resulting in part from the preponderance of [[power (international relations)|power]] enjoyed by the United States of America starting around the middle of the 20th century. Although the term finds its primary utility in the late 20th century, it has been used in other times in the 20th century. Its modern connotations concern the peace established after the end of World War II in 1945. ==Post-1945 characteristics== [[File:American Empire1.PNG|thumb|Map of United States at furthest extent]] The ''American Century'' existed through the [[Cold War]] and demonstrated the status of the United States as the foremost of the world's two superpowers. After the Cold War, the most common belief held that only the United States fulfilled the criteria to be considered a superpower. Its geographic area composed the [[List of countries and dependencies by area|fourth-largest state in the world]], with an area of approximately 9.37 million km2.[http://www.theodora.com/wfb1989/united_states/united_states_geography.html US geography] The population of the US was 248.7 million in 1990, at that time the third-largest nation.[https://www.census.gov/population/censusdata/table-2.pdf US Census] census.gov In the mid-to-late 20th century, the political status of the US was defined as a strongly capitalist federation and constitutional republic. It had a permanent seat on the [[United Nations Security Council]] plus two allies with permanent seats, the [[United Kingdom–United States relations|United Kingdom]] and [[France–United States relations|France]]. The US had strong ties with capitalist Western Europe, Latin America, [[British Commonwealth]], and several East Asian countries ([[South Korea–United States relations|Korea]], [[Republic of China–United States relations|Taiwan]], [[Japan–United States relations|Japan]]). It allied itself with both right-wing dictatorships and capitalist democracies.{{cite book|author=Stephen Kinzer |title=Overthrow: America's Century of Regime Change from Hawaii to Iraq |publisher=Times Books |year=2007}} The American Century includes the political influence of the United States but also its economic influence. Many [[State (polity)|states]] around the world would, over the course of the 20th century, adopt the economic policies of the [[Washington Consensus]], sometimes against the wishes of their populations. The economic force of the US was powerful at the end of the century due to it being by far the [[List of countries by GDP (nominal)|largest economy in the world]]. The US had large resources of minerals, energy resources, metals, and timber, a large and modernized farming industry and large industrial base. The United States dollar is the dominant world [[reserve currency]] under the [[Bretton Woods system]]. US systems were rooted in capitalist economic theory based on supply and demand, that is, production determined by customers' demands. America was allied with the [[G7]] major economies. US economic policy prescriptions were the "standard" reform packages promoted for [[Economic crisis|crisis-wracked]] [[developing country|developing countries]] by Washington, DC-based international institutions such as the [[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF), [[World Bank]], as well as the [[US Treasury Department]].Williamson, John: [http://www.iie.com/publications/papers/paper.cfm?researchid=486 What Washington Means by Policy Reform] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090625085003/http://www.iie.com/publications/papers/paper.cfm?ResearchID=486 |date=June 25, 2009 }}, in: Williamson, John (ed.): ''Latin American Readjustment: How Much has Happened'', Washington: Institute for International Economics 1989. The [[military of the United States]] was a naval-based advanced military with by far the [[List of countries by military expenditures|highest military expenditure]] in the world.[http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/spending.htm Military spending] The [[United States Navy]] was the world's largest navy, with the largest number of [[aircraft carrier]]s, bases all over the world (particularly in an incomplete "ring" bordering the [[Warsaw Pact]] states to the west, south and east). The US had the largest [[nuclear arsenal]] in the world during the first half of the Cold War, one of the largest armies in the world and one of the two largest air forces in the world. Its powerful military allies in Western Europe (the [[North Atlantic Treaty Organisation]] states) had their own nuclear capabilities. The US also possessed a powerful global intelligence network in the [[Central Intelligence Agency]]. The cultural impact of the US, often known as [[Americanization]], is seen in the influence on other countries of US music, TV, films, art, and fashion, as well as the desire for [[freedom of speech]] and other guaranteed rights its residents enjoy. US pop stars such as [[Elvis Presley]], [[Michael Jackson]], and [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] have become global celebrities.Biddle, Julian (2001). ''What Was Hot!: Five Decades of Pop Culture in America''. New York: Citadel, p. ix. {{ISBN|0-8065-2311-5}}. ==Criticism and usage== Critics have condemned Luce's "[[Jingoism|jingoistic]] missionary zeal".Michael, Terry (February 16, 2011) [http://reason.com/archives/2011/02/16/the-end-of-the-american-centur The End of the American Century], ''[[Reason magazine|Reason]]'' Others have noted the end of the 20th century and the American Century, most famously the late [[Gonzo journalism|gonzo]] journalist [[Hunter S. Thompson]] who titled his autobiography ''Kingdom of Fear: Loathsome Secrets of a Star Crossed Child in the Last Days of the American Century''. With the advent of the new [[millennium]], critics from the [[University of Illinois]] stated that it was a matter of debate whether America was losing its superpower status, especially in relation to [[Chinese Century|China's rise]].Unger J (2008), [http://www.news.uiuc.edu/news/08/0508superpower.html U.S. no longer superpower, now a besieged global power, scholars say] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006183338/http://www.news.uiuc.edu/news/08/0508superpower.html |date=October 6, 2008 }} ''University of Illinois'' Other analysts have made the case for the "American Century" fitting neatly between America's late entry into [[World War I]] in 1917 and the inauguration of its 45th President in 2017.{{Cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/business/comment-and-analysis/donald-trump-in-the-white-house-is-the-end-of-the-american-century-20170119-gtv1ae.html|title=Donald Trump in the White House is the end of the 'American Century'|last=Pascoe|first=Michael|date=January 20, 2017|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|access-date=January 21, 2017|via=}} Other scholars, such as [[George Friedman]], stipulate that the 21st century will be the U.S. century: "The twenty-first century will be the American century."Friedman, George, [https://www.amazon.com/Next-100-Years-Forecast-Century/dp/038551705X/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1498628991&sr=1-1 ''The Next 100 Years: A Forecast for the 21st Century''], p. 18 ==See also== * New American Century]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== {{Refbegin}} * {{cite book|last=Dunn|first=Dennis J. |year=1998|title=Caught Between Roosevelt & Stalin: America's Ambassadors to Moscow|location=Lexington, KY|publisher=University Press of Kentucky|isbn=978-0-8131-2023-2|ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Hogan |first=Michael J. |authorlink=Michael Hogan (academic) |year=1999 |title=The Ambiguous Legacy: U.S. Foreign Relations in The "American Century" |location=Cambridge |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-0-521-77019-4 |ref=harv}}
A symposium of scholarly articles assessing aspects of Luce's editorial and its significance originally published in ''[[Society for Historians of American Foreign Relations|Diplomatic History]]'' '''23''' (2 & 3), 1999 * {{citation|last=Karp|first=Walter|title=The Politics of War|year=1979|edition=1st|isbn=0-06-012265-X|oclc=4593327 }}, Wilson's maneuvering US into war * {{citation|last1=Langer|first1=William L.|first2=S. Painter |year=2012 |title=Oil and the American Century |url=http://jah.oxfordjournals.org/content/99/1/24.full.pdf |journal=The Journal of American History |volume=99 |issue=1 |pages=24–39 |doi=10.1093/jahist/jas073 |ref=harv}} * {{citation|last=Schmitz|first=David F. |year=2000|title=Henry L. [[File:Grob Marii Czarniewicz-Eisenbach-Grave of Maria Czarniewicz-Eisenbach.JPG|thumb|upright|Symbolic grave of Artur Eisenbach at the resting place of Maria Czarniewicz-Eisenbach (1908–1983) in Warsaw]] '''Artur Eisenbach''' (born 7 April 1906 in [[Nowy Sącz]], died 30 October 1992 in [[Tel Aviv]]) was a [[Polish-Jewish]] historian; an expert on the [[history of Jews in Poland]], member of [[Polish Academy of Sciences]] and the head of the [[Jewish Historical Institute]] in [[Warsaw]] between 1966 and 1968.<ref name=yivo>Antony Polonsky, [http://www.yivoencyclopedia.org/article.aspx/Eisenbach_Artur The YIVO encyclopedia of Jews in Eastern Europe, Volume 1, pg. 463] ''[[YIVO]] Institute for Jewish Research'', 2010.</ref>
==Life== Eisenbach studied history briefly at the Jewish Educational Seminary in Vilna and then at the [[Warsaw University]] under [[Marceli Handelsman]]. Afterwards, he worked at the Society for Jewish Health Care in Poland (Towarzystwo Ochrony Zdrowia Ludności Żydowskiej w Polsce, TOZ).<ref name=yivo/>
He married the sister of a fellow historian, and later ghetto chronicler, [[Emanuel Ringelblum]].<ref name=yivo/> After the [[Nazi invasion of Poland]] on 1 September 1939 Artur, along with his wife and child, escaped to his wife's hometown [[Kresy|in the east]], the small town of [[Buczacz]] (now Buchach, [[Ukraine]]). However, as a consequence of the Nazi-Soviet pact known as the [[Molotov-Ribbentrop Treaty]], on 17 September the Soviet Union also invaded Poland and Buczacz fell within the [[Soviet invasion of Poland|Soviet occupation zone]]. Along with 1,200,000 other Poles, Artur Eisenbach was [[Soviet repressions of Polish citizens (1939–1946)#Mass deportations to the East|deported deep within the Soviet Union]]. His wife and daughter stayed behind. In July 1941, after the [[Operation Barbarossa|Nazi Germany attacked the Soviet Union]], Buczacz was taken over by the Germans. Eisenbach's wife and daughter subsequently were murdered by the Nazis.<ref name=yivo/>
Eisenbach returned to Poland from the Soviet Union in 1946 and settled in Warsaw. In the same year he became the chief archivist of the Jewish Historical Institute (JHI) in Warsaw.<ref name=yivo/> He was a member of the PPR Polska Partia Robotnicza), the communist party in Poland from 1942 to 1948, and after 1948 member of the reconstituted PZPR (Polska Zjednoczona Partia Robotnicza). In 1966, Eisenbach became the director of the JHI and joined the [[Polish Academy of Sciences]]. In 1968, he was persecuted by the communist authorities of the [[People's Republic of Poland]] during the anti-Zionist events in the aftermath of Israel's Six Day War [[1968 Polish political crisis]] ("the March events") and forced to resign as director JHI. Unlike many other Poles of Jewish background who left Poland after these events, Artur Eisenbach chose to remain in the country and continued his studies. Subsequently, he also wrote a series of monographs on Polish Jewish history.<ref name=yivo/> He was a historical consultant on film [[Austeria]] by [[Kawalerowicz]] in 1982.
Eisenbach emigrated to [[Israel]] towards the end of his life, in 1987, where he worked at the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] and [[Yad Vashem]]. Facing terminal illness, he committed suicide in 1992.

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Use British English|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox civilian attack | title = Ballymurphy Massacre | partof = [[the Troubles]] | image = BallymurphyMassacre.jpg | caption = A [[Northern Irish murals|mural]] in Belfast commemorating the victims of the Ballymurphy Massacre. | location = [[Belfast]], [[Northern Ireland]] | coordinates = {{coord|54.575|-5.974|type:event_region:GB|display=inline,title|format=dms}} | map = {{Location map | Northern Ireland | relief = yes | width = 250 | lat = 54.575 | long = -5.974 | marksize = 5 | caption =<!--Please leave this blank--> }} | date = 9 – 11 August 1971 | time = | timezone = | type = [[Mass shooting]] | weapons = | fatalities = 11 | perp = [[Parachute Regiment (United Kingdom)|The Parachute Regiment]], [[British Army]]}}
The '''Ballymurphy Massacre''' was a series of incidents between 9 and 11 August 1971 in which the [[1st Battalion, Parachute Regiment]] of the [[British Army]] killed eleven civilians in [[Ballymurphy, Belfast]], [[Northern Ireland]], as part of [[Operation Demetrius]]. The shootings were later referred to as Belfast's Bloody Sunday, a reference to the [[Bloody Sunday (1972)|killing of civilians by the same battalion]] in [[Derry]] a few months later.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.theepochtimes.com/n2/united-kingdom/belfast-bloody-sunday-inquiry-called-for-38259.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130220194633/http://www.theepochtimes.com/n2/united-kingdom/belfast-bloody-sunday-inquiry-called-for-38259.html|archivedate=20 February 2013|title=Belfast 'Bloody Sunday' Inquiry Called For|author=Damian Robin|publisher=The Epoch Times|date=29 June 2010}}</ref>
The Northern Ireland [[The Troubles|Troubles]] had been ongoing for two years, and Belfast was particularly affected by political and sectarian violence. The British Army had been deployed in Northern Ireland in 1969, as events had got beyond the control of the [[Royal Ulster Constabulary]].
On the morning of Monday 9 August 1971, the security forces launched Operation Demetrius. The plan was to arrest and [[internment|intern]] anyone suspected of being a member of the [[Provisional Irish Republican Army]]. The unit selected for this operation was the [[Parachute Regiment (United Kingdom)|Parachute Regiment]]. Members of the Parachute Regiment stated that, as they entered the Ballymurphy area, they were shot at by republicans and returned fire.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-12511377 |title= Ballymurphy families meet First Minister Peter Robinson |publisher= BBC News |date= 18 February 2011}}</ref>
[[Mike Jackson (British Army officer)|Mike Jackson]], later to become head of the British Army, includes a disputed account of the shootings in his autobiography, and his then role as press officer for the British Army stationed in Belfast while the incidents happened.<ref>{{cite book| author = Mike Jackson|date= 2007|title = Soldier: The Autobiography | publisher = Bantam Press | isbn = 978-0593059074 }}</ref> This account states that those killed in the shootings were Republican gunmen. This claim has been strongly denied by the Catholic families of those killed in the shootings, in interviews conducted during the documentary film The Ballymurphy Precedent.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.channel4.com/programmes/massacre-at-ballymurphy | publisher = Channel 4 | website = channel4.com | title = Massacre at Ballymurphy | date = 8 September 2018 | accessdate = 14 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = https://theballymurphyprecedent.com/ | publisher = theballymurphyprecedent.com | title = The Ballymurphy Precedent - Documentary | accessdate = 14 November 2018 }}</ref>
In 2016, Sir [[Declan Morgan]], the [[Lord Chief Justice of Northern Ireland]], recommended an [[inquest]] into the killings as one of a series of "legacy inquests" covering 56 cases related to the Troubles.<ref>{{cite news|date=18 January 2016|last=Kearney|first=Vincent|title=The Troubles: Judge begins review of inquests|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-35327073|work=BBC News|location=London, UK|access-date=4 May 2016|quote=There are 56 cases involving 97 deaths. … The stalled inquests into the Army shootings of 10 people in Ballymurphy, west Belfast, in 1971, and of five more civilians in nearby Springhill a year later, were examined on the opening day in Laganside Courts.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|date=12 February 2016|title=Legacy inquests in Northern Ireland 'can be dealt with in five years'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-35562197|work=BBC News|location=London, UK|access-date=4 May 2016|quote=After a review of more than 50 outstanding cases it has been decided that all are suitable for inquest.}}</ref>
These inquests were delayed as funding was not approved by the [[Northern Ireland Executive]]. The former Stormont first minister [[Arlene Foster]] of the DUP deferred a bid for extra funding for inquests into historic killings in Northern Ireland,<ref name="irishnews_2018-03-08">{{cite web|url=http://www.irishnews.com/news/northernirelandnews/2018/03/08/arlene-foster-wrong-to-defer-bid-for-legacy-inquest-funding-says-judge-1273548/?ref=sh|title=Arlene Foster wrong to defer bid for legacy inquest funding, says judge|website=The Irish News}}</ref> a decision condemned by the human rights group [[Amnesty International]].<ref>{{cite news|date=3 May 2016|last=Kearney|first=Vincent|title=Lord Chief Justice legacy inquests plan put on hold|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-36198471|work=BBC News|location=London, UK|access-date=4 May 2016|quote=A radical plan by Northern Ireland's most senior judge to deal with inquests into some of the most controversial killings of the Troubles has been put on hold.}}</ref> Foster confirmed she had used her influence in the devolved power-sharing executive to hold back finance for a backlog of inquests connected to the conflict.<ref name="irishnews_2018-03-08"/> The High Court said "her decision to refuse to put a funding paper on the Executive basis was unlawful and procedurally flawed."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/northern-ireland/arlene-foster-will-not-pay-damages-over-blocking-legacy-inquest-funding-plan-36712780.html|title=Arlene Foster will not pay damages over blocking legacy inquest funding plan|publisher=|via=www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk}}</ref> In January 2018, the coroner's office announced that the inquest is due to begin in September 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irishnews.com/news/northernirelandnews/2018/01/19/news/coroner-in-ballymurphy-shootings-inquest-appeals-for-witnesses-to-come-forward-1236730/|title=Coroner in Ballymurphy shootings' inquest appeals for witnesses to come forward|first=Michael McHugh, Press|last=Association|website=The Irish News}}</ref>
==Timeline== [[File:Ballymurphy garden.JPG|thumb|right|Commemoration plaque in a remembrance garden in [[Ballymurphy, Belfast]]]] Six civilians were killed on 9 August, these were: *Francis Quinn (19), shot while going to the aid of a wounded man.<ref name="CAIN 9th">[http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/cgi-bin/dyndeaths.pl?querytype=date&day=9&month=08&year=1971 CAIN - Index of Deaths (9 August 1971)], caian.ulst.ac.uk; accessed 29 August 2017.</ref><ref name="guardian1">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2014/jun/26/-sp-ballymurphy-shootings-36-hours-west-belfast-northern-ireland-10-dead|publisher=The Guardian|date=26 June 2014|title=Ballymurphy shootings: 36 hours in Belfast that left 10 dead}}</ref> *Fr. Hugh Mullan (38), a [[Catholic]] priest, shot while going to the aid of a wounded man, reputedly while waving a white cloth to indicate his intentions.<ref name="CAIN 9th"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ballymurphymassacre.com/fr_hugh_mullan_10.html|title=Fr Hugh Mullan|publisher=ballymurphymassacre.com|accessdate=26 June 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100619123927/http://ballymurphymassacre.com/fr_hugh_mullan_10.html|archivedate=19 June 2010|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="mirror2018"/> *Joan Connolly (50), shot as she stood opposite the army base. It has been claimed she was shot by three different soldiers, and that she might have survived had she been given medical attention sooner, instead she laid injured in a field for several hours<ref name="CAIN 9th"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ballymurphymassacre.com/joan_connolly_12.html|title=Joan Connolly|publisher=ballymurphymassacre.com|accessdate=2010-06-26|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100619123548/http://ballymurphymassacre.com/joan_connolly_12.html|archivedate=19 June 2010|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.joe.ie/movies-tv/channel-4-troubles-documentary-639667 | publisher = Joe.ie | title = A powerful documentary on a horrific moment during The Troubles is on TV this weekend | date = 7 September 2018 | accessdate = 14 November 2018 }}</ref><ref name="mirror2018">{{cite web|url = https://www.irishmirror.ie/news/irish-news/woman-recalls-horror-moment-discovered-13162581 | publisher = Irish Mirror | website = irishmirror.ie | title = Woman recalls horror moment she discovered British army shot her innocent mother | date = 30 August 2018 | accessdate = 14 November 2018}}</ref> *Daniel Teggart (44), was shot fourteen times. Most of the bullets entered his back, allegedly as he lay injured on the ground.<ref name="CAIN 9th"/><ref>{{cite news|author= McDonald, Henry|title=Were Bloody Sunday Soldiers Involved in 'Ballymurphy Massacre'?|publisher=Guardian.co.uk|date=6 June 2010|accessdate=5 August 2011|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/jun/20/call-for-ballymurphy-massacre-inquiry}}</ref> *Noel Phillips (20), shot as he stood opposite the army base.<ref name="CAIN 9th"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ballymurphymassacre.com/noel_phillips_7.html|title=Noel Phillips|publisher=ballymurphymassacre.com|accessdate=26 June 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100621005258/http://ballymurphymassacre.com/noel_phillips_7.html|archivedate=21 June 2010|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> *Joseph Murphy (41), shot as he stood opposite the army base.<ref name="CAIN 9th"/> Murphy was subsequently taken into army custody and after his release, as he was dying in hospital, he claimed that he had been beaten and shot again while in custody. When his body was [[exhumation|exhumed]] in October 2015, a second bullet was discovered in his body, which activists say corroborate his claim.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/ireland/irish-news/bullet-found-in-body-of-exhumed-ballymurphy-massacre-victim-1.2407886|title=Bullet found in body of exhumed Ballymurphy massacre victim|author=Gerry Moriarty|publisher=[[Irish Times]]|date=27 October 2015|accessdate=29 August 2017}}</ref>
One civilian was shot on 10 August, and another four were shot on 11 August, these were: *Edward Doherty (28), shot while walking along Whiterock Road.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/cgi-bin/dyndeaths.pl?querytype=date&day=10&month=08&year=1971|title=CAIN: Sutton Index of Deaths|first=Malcolm|last=Sutton|website=cain.ulst.ac.uk}}</ref> *John Laverty (20) and Joseph Corr (43) were shot at separate points at the Top of the Whiterock Road. Laverty was shot twice, once in the back and once in the back of the leg. Corr was shot multiple times and died of his injuries on 27 August.<ref name="CAIN 9th"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ballymurphymassacre.com/joseph_corr_8.html|title=Joseph Corr|publisher=ballymurphymassacre.com|accessdate=2010-06-26|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100621005003/http://ballymurphymassacre.com/joseph_corr_8.html|archivedate=21 June 2010|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> *John McKerr (49), shot by unknown attackers while standing outside a Catholic church, died of his injuries on 20 August.<ref name="guardian1"/><ref name="CAIN 11th">[http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/cgi-bin/dyndeaths.pl?querytype=date&day=11&month=08&year=1971 CAIN - Index of Deaths (11 August 1971)], cain.ulst.ac.uk; accessed 29 August 2017.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ballymurphymassacre.com/john_kerr_16.html|title=John McKerr|publisher=ballymurphymassacre.com|accessdate=26 June 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100619124000/http://ballymurphymassacre.com/john_kerr_16.html|archivedate=19 June 2010|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> *Paddy McCarthy (44) got into a confrontation with a group of soldiers. Family allege an empty gun was put in his mouth and the trigger pulled. McCarthy suffered a [[heart attack]] and died shortly afterwards.<ref>[http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/sutton/heart.html CAIN - Index of Deaths - Sudden deaths due to heart problem during an incident], cain.ulst.ac.uk; accessed 29 August 2017.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ballymurphymassacre.com/paddy_mccarthy_15.html|title=Paddy McCarthy|publisher=ballymurphymassacre.com|accessdate=26 June 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100621005039/http://ballymurphymassacre.com/paddy_mccarthy_15.html|archivedate=21 June 2010|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In February 2015, the conviction of Terry Laverty, younger brother of John, was quashed by the [[Criminal Cases Review Commission]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Ballymurphy conviction: Terry Laverty cleared of rioting|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-31373774|date=10 February 2015|newspaper=[[BBC News Online]]}}</ref> He had been convicted of riotous behaviour and sentenced to six months on the eye-witness evidence of a private in the Parachute Regiment. The case was referred to court because the sole witness retracted his evidence.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Belfast man cleared of rioting during 1971 Ballymurphy unrest|date=10 February 2015|author=Henry McDonald|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/feb/10/belfast-man-cleared-rioting-1971-ballymurphy-unrest}}</ref>
==See also== {{Campaignbox Northern Ireland Troubles}} *[[List of massacres in Ireland]] *[[Operation Demetrius]] *[[Bloody Sunday (1972)|Bloody Sunday, 1972]]

{{color|#fc0|medium}} }} '''Dohuk Governorate''' ({{lang-ku|پارێزگای دھۆک}}, {{lang-syr|ܗܘܦܲܪܟܝܵܐ ܕܕܸܗܘܟ}} , {{lang-ar|محافظة دهوك}} Muḥāfaẓat Dahūk) is a [[Governorates of Iraq|governorate]] in [[Iraqi Kurdistan]]. Its capital is the city of [[Dohuk]]. It includes [[Zakho]], the city that meets Ibrahim Khalil [[Ibrahim Khalil border crossing|border]] between [[Turkey]] and Iraqi Kurdistan. It borders the [[Al-Hasakah Governorate]] of [[Syria]].Prior to 1976 it was part of [[Nineveh Governorate]], which was called Mosul Governorate. Dohuk Governorate is mainly inhabited by [[Kurds]] and [[Assyrian people|Assyrians]], with a small number of [[Yazidis]] and [[Armenians in Iraq|Armenians]]. The estimated population in 2017 was 1,011,585.{{cite web |url= http://www.krso.net/Default.aspx?page=article&id=1680&l=1 |title=The map of estimated population of Kurdistan Region 2017 |date=2017 |work= |publisher=Kurdistan Region Statistics Office, Kurdistan Regional Government}} ==Government== *Governor: [[Farhad Ameen Saleem Atrushi]] *Deputy Governor: [[Behzad Ali Adam]] *Governorate Council Chairman (PCC): [[Fehim Abdullah]]{{cite web|url=http://i.a.cnn.net/cnn/2007/images/04/25/un.report.pdf|date=25 April 2007|publisher=UN Assistance Mission for Iraq (UNAMI) بعثة الأمم المتحدة. 1 لتقديم المساعدة للعراق |title=Human Rights Report 1 January – 31 March 2007|accessdate=2015-09-06}} *41 total seats *33 seats for the [[Kurdistan Democratic Party of Iraq|Kurdistan Democratic Party]] (KDP) *4 seats for the [[Patriotic Union of Kurdistan]] (PUK) *4 seats for the [[Kurdistan Islamic Union]] (KIU){{cite journal |url= http://www.zindamagazine.com/html/archives/2005/4.6.05/index_wed.php |title=Assyrian Elected as Deputy Governor of Dohuk |date=6 April 2005 |volume=11 |issue=17 |work=[[Zinda Magazine]] |accessdate=13 August 2016}} ==Districts== [[File:Dihok governorate 2012.png|thumb|right|250px|Districts of the Dohuk Governorate{{cite web|url=http://www.krso.net/Default.aspx?page=article&id=1143&l=1 |title=The map of Districts of Kurdistan Region |publisher=Kurdistan Region Statistics Office, Kurdistan Regional Government}}]] Dohuk Governorate is divided into seven [[Districts of Iraq|districts]], four of which are officially part of [[Iraqi Kurdistan|Kurdistan Region]], while three others are under ''de facto'' control of the Kurdistan Regional Government: * [[Amedi District]] * [[Dohuk District]] * page.title: European hand fans in the 18th century

revision.text:
{{original research|date=August 2018}} {{refimprove|date=August 2018}} [[Hand fan]]s first arrived in [[Europe]] in the 15th century from Asia and became popular in the 16th century. Several fan styles were common and a plethora of materials were used to create them. Subject matter varied greatly, from Biblical scenes to landscapes. Hand fans serve as a cooling mechanism, [[social instrument]], and [[fashion accessory]].
== History == Fans were used throughout history, and can be traced back as long as five thousand years ago. They developed in [[ancient Egypt]], [[India]], and [[China]] where they were used for ceremonies and practical purposes.<ref name=Steele>Steele, Valerie. The Fan: Fashion and Femininity Unfolded. New York: Rizzoli, 2002. Print.</ref> In the 12th century, during the [[Crusades]], the fan was brought to Europe.<ref name=Alexander>Alexander, Hélène. Fans. London: B.T. Batsford, 1984. Print.</ref> At first, Europeans adopted the [[rigid fan]] and [[feather fan]]s. Queen [[Elizabeth I of England]] (1533–1603) owned dozens of these fans, as was shown in her portraits. Later in the 16th century, [[folding fan]]s were introduced into Europe from [[Japan]] where they originated.<ref name=Steele/>
[[File:Queen Elizabeth I ('The Ditchley portrait') by Marcus Gheeraerts the Younger.jpg|Queen Elizabeth I ('The Ditchley portrait') by Marcus Gheeraerts the Younger|thumb]]
[[File:Elizabeth I George Gower.jpg|Elizabeth I George Gower|thumb]]
Once the fan was known to Europe, [[France]] became the center for fan design and production. At the end of the 17th century, [[Huguenot]] immigrants traveled to [[England]], bringing the fan craft with them.<ref name=Alexander/> French fans were so popular that they were smuggled into England during the 18th century. During this time the [[Worshipful Company of Fan Makers]] tried to grow the English fan trade, but their success was small in comparison to the French industry.<ref name=Alexander/>
== Types == There were two main types of fans seen in Europe during the 18th century: the rigid (or fixed) fan and the folding fan.
=== Rigid fan ===
As its name implies, the rigid fan is stiff. Possible fan shapes are a leaf, a rectangle, or an oval. The fan is attached to a base where it is held.<ref name=Steele/>
=== Folding fan === The folding fan was the most popular in Europe during the 18th century, a time known as the golden age of the folding fan.<ref>"Fans." The Decoratosr and Furnisher 24.5 (1894): 182. JSTOR. Web. 10 Dec. 2010.</ref> The principal folding fan styles are pleated, brisé, and cockade.<ref name=Alexander/> [[File:Hand fan 1800 1805.jpg|Hand fan 1800 1805|thumb]]
==== Pleated fan ==== The [[pleated fan]] consists of a mount and a set of sticks. The outer sticks (the guards) are wider than the others and are often more decorated. At the base of the sticks is a pivot which connects the fan and allows it to spread and open. The base is either shaped or rounded off.<ref name=Alexander/>
==== Brisé fan ==== The [[brisé fan]] consists only of a set of sticks. These sticks are attached to a base with a pivot similar to that of a pleated fan. A cord or ribbon runs across the top of the fan, holding the sticks together.<ref name=Alexander/> [[File:Hand fan 1815 1820.jpg|Hand fan 1815 1820|thumb]]
==== Cockade fan ==== [[File:Cockade Fan YORCM TFN217.jpg|thumb|left|upright|A Parisian Cockade fan of silk and ivory, 1800-1850]] A [[cockade fan]] opens into a complete circle around the pivot. Their style can be either pleated or brisé. They were not very practical and considered too flamboyant, and thus they saw little popularity.<ref name=Alexander/>
== Materials == Fans in the 18th century were made from a wide variety of materials depending on their style and purpose. During the 18th century fans were a fashion accessory and thus were made from the fashionable materials of the time.<ref name="Mayor, Susan 1980">Mayor, Susan. Collecting Fans. New York: Mayflower, 1980. Print.</ref>
=== Sticks and handles === Sticks and handles could be made of [[gold]], [[tortoiseshell material|tortoise shell]], [[ivory]], [[mother-of-pearl]], [[horn (anatomy)|horn]], or [[wood]]. They were often highly decorated. Most sticks and handles were not only made of the previously listed materials, but were inlaid with others. For example, a mother-of-pearl fan could be inlaid with gold. Other sticks were plain.<ref name="Mayor, Susan 1980"/>
=== Mounts === Previous to 1780, mounts were typically made of [[vellum]] or [[paper]]. Some, more valuable fans were decorated with materials used for the sticks such as mother-of-pearl.<ref name="Mayor, Susan 1980"/> Other decorations included [[feather]]s, [[butterfly]] wings, [[silk]], gold, and [[sequin]]s. Although not as common, the 18th century also saw [[lace]] fans.<ref name="Mayor, Susan 1980"/>
== Subject matter == European fans were often decorated with historical, political, or social images. While some fans were meant to inform, others were meant to entertain. There was fan for every occasion; whether it be a [[wedding]], a [[funeral]], or a [[dance]], there was always a fan made specifically for the event.<ref name="Bennett, Anna G. 1981">Bennett, Anna G., and Ruth Berson. Fans in Fashion. [San Francisco]: Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, 1981. Print.</ref>
=== Entertainment === Some artists designed fans which would prevent [[boredom]] during a dull event, or would start a conversation. These fans were often covered with [[riddle]]s and [[puzzle]]s.<ref>Esdaile, Arundell. "Fans." British Museum Quarterly 14.1 (1940): 23-24. JSTOR. Web. 10 Dec. 2010.</ref> Another type of entertainment fan was the [[fortune-telling]] fan. These presented questions such as “Whether one is to get Riches; Whether one will be successful in Love; What sort of Husband shall I have; etc.”<ref name=Steele/>
=== Instructive === The 18th century saw fans which assisted in remembering [[holiday]]s or that served as [[map]]s.<ref name="Bennett, Anna G. 1981"/> The fan, “Map of Warwickshire” is such a fan.<ref name=Schreiber>Schreiber, Charlotte. Fans and Fan-Leaves. Comp. [[Lionel Cust]]. London: Oxford UP, 1893. Print.</ref>
=== Historical === Fans commonly recorded current events.<ref name="Bennett, Anna G. 1981"/> There were [[souvenir]] fans that depicted scenes such as [[Vesuvius]] erupting and the [[Coliseum]]. Others celebrated public events such as a military victory.<ref name=Steele/> The fan, “Coronation of George II” shows the banquet of [[George II of Great Britain|George II]] and [[Caroline of Ansbach|Queen Caroline]] in [[Westminster Hall]] on their [[coronation]] day, October 11, 1727.<ref name=Schreiber/>
=== Biblical and classical === Classical [[myth]]s and biblical scenes were frequent during the early 18th century.<ref name=Steele/> Fans for church depicted Bible subjects such as [[Jacob]] and [[Rachel]] or [[Ruth (biblical figure)|Ruth]] and [[Boaz]].<ref name="Bennett, Anna G. 1981"/> The fan, “Moses Striking the Rock” shows the Israelite encampment in the wilderness and [[Moses]] standing by the rock from which water flows.<ref name=Schreiber/>
=== Pastoral === Later in the 18th century, [[rococo]] pastoral scenes became popular. [[Landscape]]s were common as well as images with [[love]] and [[courtship]] themes. [[Cupid]] was often a principal figure on such fans.<ref name=Steele/> The fan, “Pastoral Landscape” shows a [[river]] landscape with men and women walking by and [[sheep]] grazing.<ref name=Schreiber/>
== Purposes ==
=== Practical === When originated, the fan’s purpose was to cool the face and keep away [[insect]]s. Before the 18th century their most common use was to keep flies away from church [[altar]]s.<ref>Standen, Edith. "Acquisitions of Works of Art by Museums and Galleries: Supplement." The Burlington Magazine 107.750 (1965): 487. JSTOR. Web. 10 Dec. 2010.</ref> While driving insects away became less and less of a fan’s purpose, the fan continued to serve as a cooling mechanism.<ref name=Alexander/>
=== Fashion === In Europe, fans were not a necessity. They were mainly used as a fashion accessory, to complement the rest of the lady’s outfit. “Fans were as much an adjunct to a lady of fashion’s attire as were gloves or bags.”<ref name=Alexander/> By the 18th century fans were used only by females. The fan was described as the “feminine accessory, par excellence.”<ref name=Steele/>
=== Propaganda === Subject matter such as historical and political events made fans a means of spreading [[news]] or political [[propaganda]]. Other fans contained [[brand name]]s and store fronts and thus acted as [[advertisement]]s.<ref name=Alexander/>
=== Social instrument – fan language === Due to their large use and popularity, fans began to affect [[gesture]]s and thus a fan “[[sign language]]” developed between 1711 and 1740.<ref name="Bennett, Anna G. 1981"/> In a 1740 edition of the [[Gentleman's Magazine]], there was an advertisement for “The New Fashioned Speaking FAN!”<ref name=Steele/> This “speaking fan” created a system whereby motions of the fan translated into letters of the alphabet. The alphabet, with the exception of J, was split into five sections. These sections corresponded to one of the following movements:
# Moving the fan with the left hand to the left arm # Moving the fan with the right hand to the left arm # Placing the fan against the bosom # Raising the fan to the mouth # Raising the fan to the forehead
In order to signal a letter two movements were necessary. The first corresponded to one of the five [[alphabet group]]s, and the second told the letter’s position in the group. For example, to signal “D”, one would use movement 1 (first section of the alphabet), followed by movement 4 (fourth letter in that section of the alphabet).<ref name=Steele/>
== Current status == {{Time-context|section|date=August 2018}} Fans are often considered minor works of art.{{according to whom?|date=August 2018}} Many survived and are in the hands of owners or museums throughout the world.<ref name=Alexander/>
== References == {{reflist}}

page.title: Frédéric Charles Jean Gingins de la Sarraz

revision.text:
'''Frédéric Charles Jean Gingins de la Sarraz''' (14 August 1790, [[Éclépens]] – 27 February 1863, [[Lausanne]]) was a Swiss [[historian]] and [[botanist]].
From 1817 to 1828 he worked as a translator of the French language in the State Chancellery at [[Bern]]. In 1844 he received an honorary doctorate from the [[University of Bern]] and in 1854 was awarded an honorary professorship at the [[University of Lausanne|Academy of Lausanne]].<ref name=SH>[http://www.hls-dhs-dss.ch/textes/f/F31578.php Dictionnaire historique de la Suisse] biography</ref>
As a historian, he published numerous works from 1833 up until his death in 1863, most notably writings associated with the [[Kingdom of Burgundy|First and Second Kingdoms of Burgundy]].<ref name=SH/> In 1837 he was a founding member of the ''Société d'histoire de la Suisse romande'', and from 1840 was a full member of the ''Académie des sciences, belles-lettres et arts de Savoie''.<ref>[http://cths.fr/an/prosopo.php?id=103590 Prosopo] Sociétés savantes de France</ref>
In 1823 he published a treatise on the botanical family [[Violaceae]] titled "''Mémoire sur la famille des Violacées''".<ref name=GG>[https://www.google.com/search?tbo=p&tbm=bks&q=inauthor:%22Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric+de+Gingins-+la+Sarra%22 Google Books] published works</ref> As a [[taxonomic authority|taxonomist]] he described a number of species within the genus ''[[Viola (plant)|Viola]]''.<ref>[http://www.ipni.org/ipni/advPlantNameSearch.do?find_includePublicationAuthors=on&find_includePublicationAuthors=off&find_includeBasionymAuthors=on&find_includeBasionymAuthors=off&find_rankToReturn=all&output_format=normal&find_authorAbbrev=Ging. IPNI] List of taxa described and co-described by Gingins de la Sarraz.</ref> In 1828 [[Augustin Pyramus de Candolle]] named the genus ''Ginginsia'' in his honor.<ref>[https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/33121079#page/996/mode/1up BHL] Taxonomic literature : a selective guide to botanical publications</ref>
== Selected historical works == * ''Essai historique sur la souveraineté du Lyonnais'', etc., 1835 – Historical essay on the sovereignty of 10th century [[Lyonnais]]. * ''Essai sur lʹétablissement des Burgunden dans la Gaule et sur le partage des terres entréaux et les régnicoles'', 1838 – Essay on the establishment of the Burgundians in [[Gaul]], etc. * ''Lettres sur la guerre des Suisses contre le duc Charles-le-Hardi'', 1839 – Letters on the war of the Swiss against the duke [[Charles the Bold]]. * ''Développement de lʹindependance du Haut-Vallais et conquête du Bas-Vallais'', 1844 – Development concerning the independence of Haut-Valais and the conquest of [[Bas-Valais]]. * ''Documents pour servir à l'histoire des comtes de Biandrate'', 1847 – Documents used for the history associated with the counts of [[Biandrate]]. * ''Episodes des guerres de Bourgogne'': ao. 1474 à 1476, (1849) – Episodes of the [[Burgundian Wars]]: ao. 1474–1476. * ''Les Hugonides'', 1853. * ''Histoire de la ville dʹOrbe et du son chateau dans le moyen age'', 1855 – History of the town of [[Orbe]] and its castle in the Middle Ages. * ''Histoire de la cité et du canton des Équestres, suivie de divers autres opuscules'', 1865 – History of the city and canton of Equestres.<ref name=GG/>
{{Botanist|Ging.|Gingins de la Sarraz, Frédéric Charles Jean}}
== References == {{reflist}}
